abstract.abstracttext:
To compare the efficacy and safety of
viscocanalostomy
and
trabeculectomy
in
patients
with primary open angle glaucoma .
Department of Ophthalmology, Ankara Education and Research Hospital, Ankara, Turkey.

In this prospective randomized trial, 50 eyes of 50 patients with medically uncontrolled Primary Open Angle Glaucoma were randomized to have a trabeculectomy (25 eyes) or a viscocanalostomy (25 eyes). Visual acuity, intraocular pressure , and slitlamp examinations were performed before surgery and _POFT_, _POFT_, _POFT_, _POFT_, and _POFT_, and _POFT_, _POFT_, and _POFT_ postoperatively.

At _POFT_, the mean
Intraocular Pressure
was
16.0 +/ 7.07 mmHg
in the trabeculectomy group and
17.8 +/ 4.6 mmHg
in the viscocanalostomy group _PVAL_. Complete success (Intraocular Pressure 6 to 21 mmHg without medication) was achieved in 66.2% of eyes at _POFT_ and _POFT_.1% at _POFT_ in the trabeculectomy group and in 52.9% and 35.3%, respectively, in the viscocanalostomy group _PVAL_. Qualified success (Intraocular Pressure 6 to 21 mmHg with medication) was achieved in 95.8% of eyes at _POFT_ and _POFT_.2% at _POFT_ in the trabeculectomy group and in 90.7% and 73.9%, respectively, in the viscocanalostomy group _PVAL_. Postoperative hypotony and cataract formation occurred more frequently in the trabeculectomy group than in the viscocanalostomy group _PVAL_.
Primary trabeculectomy lowered Intraocular Pressure more than viscocanalostomy in Primary Open Angle Glaucoma patients. However, the complication rate was lower in the viscocanalostomy group.

body.title: Primary viscocanalostomy versus trabeculectomy for primary open-angle glaucoma: three-year prospective randomized clinical trial.
